content:
The constraint that states "Divisions(/) are rounded down to the nearest whole number" doesn't match the test cases. 

For test 4, "2/8-3" equals -3 if you round the division 2/8 down to 0, but the test expects only "2-8+3" as a valid solution. 

If we must round down the result after the entire expression is evaluated, there is still an issue. 2/8-3 = -2.75, which is -3 when rounding down (math.floor(-2.75)==-3 is true). int(-2.75) is not the same as rounding down, it simply truncates the float.

This test should be fixed or the constraint needs clarification.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice contribution

Nice interesting challenge.
Be cautious, since you added "/" operation the number of possible expressions is now 4x4x4 = 64.
Last line of your 1st section is not very clear. Here is a proposition : 
" Answer if there is only one equation in the equation you created whose answer is d"
=> "Count how many of those expressions result in the answer d
       If there is one, output the formula
       ...."

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good contribution.

I changed a little the format of the examples in the statement so it looks better.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear statement even if maybe a bit verbose for CoC. Fun and of appropriate difficulty. Working tests/validators and doable in < 5mins :thumbsup:.

Maybe consider adding "/" to the list of possible operations so one has to think a bit more about zero divisions.

Pairs of test cases and validators should be similar in coverage, so I would suggest:
* Validator 1 and Validator 3 be swapped.
* 1 more validator which requires output of -1 to pair with test 2.
* 1 more test which requires using the minus sign to output a negative number to pair with validator 4.

Thank you.
Thanks for teaching me about validators and test cases. I learned a lot because I now have a better understanding of validators and test cases.
I have changed some of the validators and test cases.

Thanks for the good ideas.
I added the division. Also added more test cases.

Thank you.
I have corrected the Goal section sentences.

Thank you.
I have changed the Constraints statement.
Specifically, I have changed the constraint to allow a decimal point in the division, but truncate the decimal point in the final answer.
Although I wrote the program question, my understanding of the eval function was not very good, and I finally realized it when you pointed it out to me this time.
My knowledge has deepened. Thanks.

Thank you.
But you did not correct the total number of expressions that can be created (you wrote 9).
It could be misunderstanding for players since the real number of expression is rather 64 (if I'm not wrong in my calculus)

Thank you.
I forgot to correct the numbers. Thanks for saying that again.
Since there are two places to put the operations, there were two for statements, and before the fix it was '+-*', so 3x3, 9 ways.
After this modification, it is '+-*/', so I think 4x4 is 16 ways, so I changed it to 16.
